ID1.question: How are SBOMs (Software Bill of Materials) used in your projects? Please select all options that pertain to the projects you contribute to:

roles.producer: We create SBOMs for the software that we produce
roles.consumer: We use or analyze the SBOMs of other projects (including our dependencies)
roles.familiar_non_user: I am familiar with SBOMs, but we do not use them in our projects

S1.question: Indicate your agreement with the following statement: “Other well known / well established open source projects are producing SBOMs"

S2.question: Indicate your agreement with the following statement: “Other well known / well established open source projects are consuming SBOMs"

S3.question: As an open source project, do you publish a list of your project's dependencies?

S4.question: How do your projects obtain the list of dependencies? Are there any specific tools or techniques used to that end?

S5.question: Why do your projects not publish their dependencies?

FS1.question: Which SBOM formats/standards do your projects use? Select all that apply.

FS2.question: Indicate your agreement with the following statement: “The use of SBOMs is critical in software development"

FS3.question: Indicate your agreement with the following statement: “Current SBOM standards / specifications meet the needs of users and industry”

FS4.question: Which of the following deficiencies have you or your projects encountered in current SBOM standards / specifications? Select all that apply.

FS5.question: How can we address (some of) the selected deficiencies in SBOM standards / specifications?

FS6.question: Indicate your agreement with the following statement: “Current SBOM tool support meets the needs of users.”

FS7.question: What are some issues that you or your projects have encountered in SBOM tooling (tools that generate/process SBOMs)?

FS8.question: How can we address current deficiencies in SBOM tooling? Select all that apply.

FS9.question: Do your projects have a process/method to verify whether SBOMs completely and correctly report all dependencies and their metadata?

FS10.question: What process/method do your projects have to verify whether SBOMs completely and correctly report all dependencies and their metadata?

NU1.question: What tools and/or techniques do you use for dependency management in your software projects?

NU2.question: Why do you prefer these tools and/or techniques over other methods?

P1.question: Select all statements that apply to your projects:

P2.question: At what point(s) in the software development process should SBOMs be generated? Select all that apply.

P3.question: Why do your projects create SBOMs? Select all that apply.

P4.question: What benefits have your projects observed from producing SBOMs? Select all that apply.

P5.question: What tools do your projects use to assist in the creation of SBOMs, if any?

P6.question: Do your projects have any strategies for managing SBOM versions?

P7.question: What strategies do your projects have for managing SBOM versions? Are there any specific tools involved?

P8.question: What issues have your projects encountered when producing SBOMs? Select all that apply.

IP1.question: Do your projects share their SBOMs externally?

IP2.question: Why are your projects' SBOMs not shared externally?

EP1.question: How do your projects publish / distribute your created SBOMs? Select all that apply.

C1.question: What do your projects use SBOMs for? Select all that apply.

C2.question: Which of the following benefits have your projects observed from using SBOMs? Select all that apply.

C3.question: How often do your projects use SBOMs during software development?

C4.question: Do your projects process or analyze the SBOMs of their software dependencies (if available)?

C5.question: How do your projects process or analyze the SBOMs of their dependencies? What tools, if any, are involved in the process?

C6.question: Which of the following issues have your projects encountered in using SBOMs? Select all that apply.

C7.question: How do you prefer the SBOMs of other projects to be shared with you? Rank by preference (by dragging the options).
options: Stored with a trusted third party
Located in repositories along with the source code
Available from the project developers upon request

FN1.question: Which of the following SBOM formats have you heard of?

FN2.question: Have you used SBOMs in the past?

FN3.question: Why do you not currently use SBOMs?

O1.question: Are you familiar with Operations Bills of Materials (OBOMs)?

O2.question: How would you describe OBOMs? What are their key features?

O3.question: Do you use OBOMs in your projects?

O4.question: What should OBOMs be used for?

Q1.question: How many years of experience in software development do you have?

Q2.question: How would you describe your primary role?

Q3.question: What is your highest level of education?

Q4.question: Which programming languages have you most used in past projects? Select all that apply.

Q5.question: What types of systems have you developed?

Q6.question: For which domains (e.g., banking or healthcare) have you developed applications / systems?

Q7.question: Do you primarily work on open source or closed source projects?

Q8.question: Do you have a background in computer security? Formal (college classes, degree, certification) or informal (self-learning or other training)?

Q9.question: Do you have a background in software licensing? Formal (college classes, degree, certification) or informal (self-learning or other training)?

Q10.question: How often did you release or help release a new major version of an application / software over the past two years? Please give your best estimate; if you develop more than one software / application, please answer based on the most frequently updated software / application.

Q11.question: Which country / countries are you and / or your organization based in?

Q12.question: Please enter your email address. This will be used to contact you for compensation. If we are interested in your responses, we may contact you for a follow-up interview, if you are willing.
